newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai brokers threatened as stock exchange slides.
newsitem.headline: Thai brokers threatened as stock exchange slides.

text.p: Some Thai brokers are taking security precautions following threats from disgruntled investors hit by a tumbling stock market, industry sources said.
Irate investors, who stood to lose fortunes if brokers force-sold their deteriorating portfolios, had tried to stave off such action by making threats, the sources said.
Under the forced-sales system, brokers compel clients to sell stocks bought on credit to cover portfolio losses.
A number of firms had received threats of varying degrees over the past few months, the sources said.
Thailand's stock market has plunged to 3-1/2-year lows on the back of blue-chip sales by mainly foreign investors. The market was down 7.08 points to 828.63 at midday on Monday.
The sales have also been sparked by worries about Thailand's economic fundamentals, especially the large 1996 current account deficit which is projected at 8.2 percent of gross domestic product.

Other investors' concerns were the deteriorating quality of bank loans given to firms in the depressed Thai property sector, official projections for a contraction in 1996 export growth and a slowing of the robust economy.

"I think this problem may have happened to some brokers with margin accounts making big losses in the market, if the broker has forced clients to sell," said Sasitorn Withayaruksun, head of sales at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Although intimidation against individuals is rare in Thailand, some serious business disputes are sometimes settled violently. So some executives are not taking chances.
"One country manager has hired bodyguards after receiving threats," said George Morgan, head of the Foreign Brokers Association. "Though I think this is an isolated case."

Traders at a Japanese brokerage said a package containing a severed dog's head had been sent to a company employee. But executives clarified that it was not market-related and was triggered by a personality clash between two employees.

Threats against brokers were widespread, but foreign securities companies had been targeted because they were generally less flexible in relaxing forced-sale rules than some local securities houses, brokers said.
The market has become more sensitive to negative reports and recommendations with the key SET Index having lost over 30 percent of its value since the start of the year.
A Hong Kong-Thai joint venture brokerage executive said his firm was among those targeted by losers for taking a bearish stance on the market this year.
"I think the real issue is that some important people have been forced to sell and have lost money and they just don't like it," said the executive, who declined to be named.
